verse: In the eighteenth year of King Jeroboam, Abijah became king over Judah.
He ruled for three years in Jerusalem. His motherâ€™s name was Micaiah, the daughter of Uriel from Gibeah.

Abijah got ready for battle with an army of four hundred thousand strong warriors, each man specially chosen. Jeroboam lined up for battle against him with eight hundred thousand strong warriors, each man specially chosen.
Abijah stood on Mount Zemaraim in the hill country of Ephraim and said this to them:
However, Jeroboam had set up an ambush to come around them from behind. So the main enemy forces were in front of Judah, and the ambush was behind them.
When Judah turned and saw that the battle line was in front of them and behind them, they cried out to the Lord while the priests kept blowing the trumpets.
The men of Judah raised a battle cry. When they raised the battle cry, God defeated Jeroboam and all Israel before Abijah and Judah.
The men of Israel fled from Judah, and God gave them into their hand.
Abijah and his people inflicted very heavy casualties on them. Five hundred thousand specially chosen men of Israel fell in battle.
So the men of Israel were subdued at that time. The men of Judah prevailed because they relied on the Lord, the God of their fathers.
Abijah pursued Jeroboam and took these cities from him: Bethel and its villages, Jeshanah and its villages, and Ephron and its villages.
Jeroboam never recovered his power during the days of Abijah. Then the Lord struck Jeroboam, and he died.
But Abijah grew strong. He took for himself fourteen wives and fathered twenty-two sons and sixteen daughters.
The rest of the acts of Abijah, his ways and his words, are written in the notes of the prophet Iddo.
